sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with singular matrices
message_1:
Consider the following system of linear equations:

2x + y = 3

4x + 2y = 6

If we write this system in matrix form, we get:

\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 6 \end{bmatrix}

Use matrix algebra to solve the system by finding the inverse of the coefficient matrix. Check whether the matrix is singular or not.
message_2:
To find the inverse of the coefficient matrix, we first need to check if the matrix is invertible. A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero. The determinant of a 2x2 matrix is calculated as follows:

det(A) = ad - bc

where A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}

In our case, the matrix A is:

A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 2 \end{bmatrix}

So, the determinant is:

det(A) = (2)(2) - (1)(4) = 4 - 4 = 0

Since the determinant is 0, the matrix A is singular, which means it is not invertible. Therefore, we cannot find the inverse of the coefficient matrix to solve the system of linear equations using matrix algebra.
